coredata.dc:title: Computer simulation using a non-spherical reference potential for polar fluids
coredata.dc:creator: Williams, C.P.
Gupta, S.
McLaughlin, E.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A Barker—Henderson type splitting of the intermolecular potential has been used to obtain a non-spherical reference potential for a perturbation theory of polar fluids. Monte Carlo simulations of the non-spherical reference fluid have been performed to obtain directly the reference fluid Helmholtz free energy A 0, and the first-order free-energy term A 1. Resulting first-order expansion predicts reasonably well thermodynamic properties for the case of dipolar Lennard-Jones fluids; however, serious deviations are noted for the case of quadrupolar Lennard-Jones fluids.

McLAUGHLIN Department of Chemical Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803-7303, USA Received 20 June 1987 A Barker-Henderson type splitting of the intermolecular potential has been used to obtain a non-spherical reference potential for a perturbation theory of polar fluids. Monte Carlo simulations of the non-spherical reference fluid have been performed to obtain directly the reference fluid Helmholtz free energy Ay, and the first-order free-energy term A i. Resulting first-order expan- sion predicts reasonably well thermodynamic properties for the case of dipolar Lennard-Jones fluids; however, serious deviations are noted for the case ofquadrupolar Lennard-Jones fluids. 1. Introduction The idea of using perturbation theory to predict thermodynamic properties of dense fluids was first suggested by Longuet-Higgins [ 1 ], who related the free energy of a non-ideal solution to that of an ideal one by expanding the free energy in terms of a per- turbation potential. The perturbation theory approach was proposed independently by Barker [2] who expanded the partition function of a polar fluid about that of isotropic molecules. Later Zwanzig [ 3 ] showed how the free energy of a dense atomic fluid, interacting with some isotropic pair potential U(r) could be related to that of a hard-sphere fluid with a potential Uo(r) by performing a Taylor series expansion of the canonical partition function, and in particular the configurational integral. Zwanzig obtained the following expression for the Helmholtz free energy, (1) Ao is the Helmholtz energy of the reference fluid and A i, the first-order term, is given by A^Ao+(Np/2)^U, (r)go(r) dr, (2) where Ui(r) is the perturbation potential, go(r) is the radial distribution function of the reference fluid, N is the number of molecules, p is the number den- sity, and r is the intermolecular separation. For the fluids of non-spherical molecules two per- turbation expansions have been proposed [4]; u- expansion and expansion, which both utilize angle- averaged spherical reference potentials. Conver- gence of these two expansions is slow and a "Pade approximant" is usually applied to obtain improved convergence of the expansion [4]. Non-spherical reference potentials have also been considered. Mo and Gubbins [5] have studied the application of a non-spherical reference along the lines of Weeks-Chandler-Anderson [6] theory. Recently, Wojcik and Gubbins [7] studied a Barker- Henderson [8] type non-spherical reference for fluids of hard-quadrupolar dumb-bells with point charges. A similar approach has been developed by Kohler and Quirke [9] who used a slightly different form of the orientation-dependent reference potential. This method has been applied to polar Lennard-Jones diatomic fluids and, as a special case involving zero elongations, Lennard-Jones dipolar and quadrupolar fluids have been studied. To obtain Ao, a hard-dumb- bell fluid was used [9] to model the reference fluid which reduces to a hard sphere for the case of zero elongations. We note that g(r) values for the full quadru- polar and dipolar fluids are also very close as expected, although a direct comparison is not shown here. A comparison of the g(r) values obtained from simulations using the full potential with those using the non-spherical reference potential shows the effect of attractive forces is to bring molecules closer to each other for both dipolar and quadrupolar fluids. The comparison also shows that the locations of the max- ima in g(r) are relatively unaffected by attractive forces. Perhaps the most interesting point here is the close agreement, for both dipolar and quadrupolar fluids, between the numerical solution of the Percus-Yevick equation and results from simula- tions using the non-spherical reference potential. This demonstrates that eq. (7) is a valid approximation, at least for obtaining the angle-averaged pair distri- bution function of the reference fluid defined by eqs. (3a) and (3b). We note that this approximation has been used by Kohler and Quirke [9] in their devel- opment of a perturbation theory for polar fluids. The anisotropic contribution is defined here as the difference between the properties of a bulk polar fluid and the corresponding non-polar fluid at the same density and temperature. In a sense this is a severe test, although less realistic, since total molar properties are needed in most applications. How- ever, comparison of the anisotropic contribution makes our work consistent with the existing litera- ture. Here it must be remembered that the first-order Barker-Henderson theory is inadequate even for the Lennard-Jones fluid. For the case of dipolar fluids Monte Carlo per- turbation calculations consistently overpredict the anisotropic contribution to the Helmholtz free energy. Comparison of the perturbation theory cal- culations using Monte Carlo with molecular dynam- ics simulations using the full potential is very consistent and some of the deviation at fi*= 1.0 can be attributed to computational errors of the order of 0.05 in AA/NkTin both these methods. For the case 253 Volume 140, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 2 October 1987 of quadrupolar fluids, MC perturbation theory underpredicts the anisotropic contribution to the Helmholtz free energy. A comparison of the pertur- bation calculations using Monte Carlo with simula- tions using the full polar pair potential clearly shows the consistency of deviations with respect to density. We also note that the perturbation theory of Kohler and Quirke [9] works just as well as our Monte Carlo calculations for the case of dipolar fluids and even better for the case of quadrupolar fluids. It appears that while the comparisons are quite good for dipolar fluids, serious underpredictions of the Helmholtz free energy are noted for quadrupolar fluids. This comparison supports the observation by Gray and Gubbins [4] that expansion using this type of non-spherical reference works better for dipolar fluids. Wojcik and Gubbins [7] observed similar behaviour using the first-order Monte Carlo pertur- bation calculations for fluids of hard dumb-bells with point-charge quadruples. In this case it was shown, also using Monte Carlo simulations, that a second- order term was needed for improved convergence of the expansion. Clearly, the g(r) comparison shows the need for higher-order terms and we will try to perform second-order computations in the future. Recently there has been an interest in utilizing the median potential theory, and properties of non-polar diatomic fluids have been predicted using this the- ory with reasonable success [ 17,18 ]. It has been sug- gested by MacGowan et al. [17] that this approach fails for polar fluids such as dipolar hard spheres if the original procedure of MacGowan et al. [17] is used which would lead to a hard sphere as the median potential. However, in a more recent approach, MacGowan [18] has studied the separation of potentials into anisotropic reference and perturba- tion parts. Application of the median potential the- ory and recombination of the sphericalized reference and perturbation parts can then be used to obtain the sphericalized potential. This method successfully predicts properties of a fluid whose molecules have a non-spherical core without explicitly modeling a non-spherical hard molecule. Clearly this approach can also be applied to polar fluids if a split according to eqs. (3a) and (3b) is used. Acknowledgement We thank Professor J.M.
